title: Macron says he'll name new PM in the next few days, vows to remain in office
summary: The French president spoke after the resignation of Prime Minister Michel Barnier, whose government was toppled by a no-confidence vote in Parliament.

title: Barnier's fall puts Macron back in spotlight, but under pressure from his allies
summary: Following the topping of Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government, President Emmanuel Macron is looking to solve an unprecedented power vacuum amid the budget debate, while facing calls from the opposition to resign.

title: Barnier's downfall: The day of a foregone failure
summary: The left and the far right came together to overthrow the shortest-serving prime minister in the French Fifth Republic.

title: Le Pen defends decision to topple French government as 'reasonable'
summary: Marine Le Pen and her MPs sought to downplay the consequences of a decision that is worrying its supporters, and even those within their own ranks.

title: Mercosur free-trade agreement: Ursula von der Leyen's imminent decision to sign the deal marks the retreat of French influence
summary: The Commission president is on her way to Montevideo, Uruguay, for the Mercosur summit, where she could ratify the treaty despite Paris's categorical and repeated opposition.

title: Lawmakers toppled the French government. What happens now?
summary: With the success of a motion of no confidence against Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government, the period of political uncertainty is set to intensify.

title: NASA's stuck astronauts hit 6 months 'living in space': 'Super fun'
summary: While NASA managers bristle at calling the two retired Navy captains stuck or stranded, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams shrug off the description. They insist they're fine and accepting of their fate. Wilmore views it as a detour of sorts: 'We're just on a different path.'

title: Russian foreign minister says Russia ready to defend itself through 'any means'
summary: Sergei Lavrov, in an interview with Trump ally and media personality Tucker Carlson on Thursday, said, 'we would be ready to use any means not to allow them to succeed in what they call strategic defeat of Russia,' referencing the US and its allies.

title: In Islamist-controlled Aleppo, a time of uncertainty
summary: The rebel group Hayat Tahrir al Sham is stepping up its reassuring messages to the inhabitants of the large city in northern Syria. But mistrust remains towards this jihadist movement, particularly among Christians.

title: EU chief in last-gasp push to close South America trade deal
summary: Von der Leyen arrived in Uruguay on Thursday for a two-day summit of leaders from Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, the four countries with which the European Union hopes to create the world's biggest free trade zone.

title: House rejects Democratic efforts to force release of Matt Gaetz ethics report
summary: Gaetz has repeatedly denied the claims of sexual misconduct. While ethics reports have previously been released after a member's resignation, it is extremely rare. Most Republicans have argued that any congressional probe into Gaetz ended when he resigned from the House.

title: In Germany, Chancellor Olaf Scholz and his conservative rival Friedrich Merz clash over military aid to Ukraine
summary: In the run-up to the February parliamentary elections, the Social Democrat leader is posing as the Chancellor of Peace. His Christian Democrat opponent is in favor of supplying Kyiv with Taurus medium-range missiles.

title: In Turkey, a TV series that mirrors society: From ban to audience success
summary: 'Red Roses' tells the story of the encounter between a man and a woman from opposite backgrounds. He is an uncompromising Kemalist psychiatrist; she is a pious, troubled mother and member of a religious brotherhood, whose growing influence in the country is highlighted by the series.

title: 7.0 magnitude earthquake sparks brief tsunami warning in California
summary: The powerful earthquake was recorded off the coast of Northern California at a depth of just 10 kilometers, striking at 10:44 am local time. Smartphone users had initially received warnings urging them to move to higher ground immediately.

title: Footprints in Kenya reveal the cohabitation of two hominin species
summary: These 1.5 million-year-old footprints left in the mud of a lake suggest that 'Homo erectus' and 'Paranthropus boisei' shared the territory.

title: Georgian President Salomé Zourabichvili: 'This is a vital moment for the country, and I hope the outcome will not be tragic'
summary: In an interview with Le Monde, the pro-European president of the former Soviet republic in the Caucasus said that the pro-Russian ruling party, Georgian Dream, is today 'very isolated.'

title: Amnesty International accuses Israel of 'genocide' in Gaza
summary: The London-based rights organization said its findings were based on satellite images documenting devastation, fieldwork and ground reports from Gazans as well as 'dehumanizing and genocidal statements by Israeli government and military officials.'

title: Notre-Dame's 340,000 donors
summary: 'The story of Notre-Dame' (3/5). Two days after the April 15, 2019 fire, pledges to rebuild the Paris cathedral had already amounted to €900 million. After five years of restoration work, the reopening, on December 7 and 8, will honor the largest donors, alongside heads of state.

title: Thousands rally in Romania for pro-European presidential runner
summary: In the first-round on November 24, far right outsider Calin Georgescu, a past admirer of Russian President Vladimir Putin, took the most votes, sparking fears about the future of the EU and NATO member and triggering protests especially among young people.

title: Biden at his final tree lighting, shares wish for US to 'continue to seek the light of liberty and love'
summary: The tree lighting ceremony at the White House is an annual tradition. Trombone Shorty and Trisha Yearwood were among the performers on Thursday.

title: 'Macron is primarily responsible for France's unprecedented and hazardous political situation'
summary: The French president, brushing aside calls to resign, is looking to appear as the guarantor of the country's institutions. Rather than recomposing French political life as he had hoped to, he has accelerated its decomposition, Le Monde's Solenn de Royer writes in her column.

title: Trump names ex-senator Perdue as pick for US ambassador to China
summary: David Perdue, 74, a business executive and politician, served as a senator for Georgia from 2015 to 2021, and failed in a bid for governor of the state in 2022. On Thursday, Trump also named former PayPal chief operating officer David Sacks as White House 'AI and Crypto Czar.'

title: The Syrian National Army, a rebel group loyal to Turkey
summary: The sudden advance of armed groups hostile to the Damascus regime plays into the hands of Ankara, which controls these militias – who are also hostile to the Kurds.

title: Paul Magnette, leader of Belgium's Socialists: 'France's political rules make parliamentary democracy very difficult'
summary: In an interview with 'Le Monde,' the president of Belgium's Socialist Party argues that France's two-round majority system generates a culture that is the antithesis of parliamentary compromise.

title: South Korean ruling party says 'dangerous' president must go
summary: If President Yoon Suk Yeol remains, 'there is a significant risk that extreme actions similar to the martial law declaration could be repeated, which could put the Republic of Korea and its citizens in great danger,' Han Dong-hoon, the head of Yoon's People Power Party, said Friday.

title: In India, the Adani empire is faltering
summary: Built with the unwavering support of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, businessman Gautam Adani's conglomerate, estimated to be worth over $56 billion, is under investigation by the US justice system for corruption.

title: War in Ukraine: 'Yulia Mykytenko's story is a war diary, a portrait of a big-hearted patriot and a moral lesson'
summary: Le Monde's Alain Frachon looks back at the journey and commitment of the young Ukrainian lieutenant, described in a book by French-American journalist Lara Marlowe, which is indispensable for understanding the war in Ukraine.

title: Macron looks to reassure but refuses to take on 'responsibilities of others'
summary: In a televised address on Thursday, Macron pledged to appoint a prime minister 'within the next few days.' Despite increasing calls for his resignation, he firmly ruled out stepping down before the end of his term.

title: To solve budget impasse, Macron banks on emergency 'special law' and new bill in 2025
summary: With efforts to pass the 2025 budget having failed, President Emmanuel Macron said a special law would be introduced in the next 10 days to ensure the government could keep operating after December 31.

title: France risks an institutional crisis
summary: The failure of Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government reflects France's struggle to adopt a culture of compromise. Between now and June 2025 – when the Assemblée Nationale can be dissolved again – two dangers must be avoided: gridlock and the growing influence of the far right.

title: Notre-Dame, 'France's most visited monument,' will welcome back millions of tourists
summary: The cathedral was the most visited monument in France before its closure, with 12 million visitors a year. It will reopen to the public on December 8.

title: Germany pushes for Mercosur deal: 'Must not miss unique opportunity'
summary: Berlin urged 'pragmatism' and 'compromise' to finalize the world's largest free-trade zone, while France, Italy and Poland have voice strong opposition over environmental and economic concerns.

title: UK's Guardian agrees to sell 233-year-old Sunday paper 'The Observer'
summary: Despite staff strikes, the Guardian Media Group finalized a deal with Tortoise Media to sell the world's oldest Sunday newspaper for £25 million.

title: Macron meets with Socialists amid talks to form new government
summary: Socialist leader Olivier Faure said he was ready to negotiate, but that there should be 'reciprocal concessions'. Right-wing Interior Minister Bruno Retailleau said the right would 'make no compromise' with the left.

title: European Union and Mercosur conclude free trade deal
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced negotiations with the South American bloc were complete.

title: Prince William to attend Notre Dame cathedral reopening
summary: King Charles's son will represent the UK alongside dozens of heads of state and government at the ceremony.

title: Hundreds in Chad call for French forces to leave
summary: Up to 500 people carrying placards that read 'bar France' gathered at the N'Djamena stadium draped in the African country's colors.

title: Kazakhstan holds talks with France on first nuclear power plant
summary: The Uranium-rich nation, which suffers from chronic energy shortages, approved plans to build a nuclear power plant in a referendum earlier this year, despite lingering resentment over massive radiation exposure from Soviet-era nuclear tests.

title: Romania's top court annuls presidential election
summary: The country's Constitutional Court made the decision following allegations of Russian interference, effectively canceling the second-round run-off that had been due to take place this weekend.

title: Loss of Hama is another stinging defeat for the Syrian regime
summary: On Wednesday, the insurgent coalition led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham took control of Hama, Syria's fourth-largest city, and is advancing rapidly towards Homs.

title: 'President Yoon wanted to set up a National Assembly at his command'
summary: Popular political commentator Kim Ou-joon was a target of the martial law imposed by South Korea's president, Yoon Suk Yeol. Having escaped the military who came to his home, he agreed to answer Le Monde's questions, shedding light on the president's plan.

title: The great silence of Notre-Dame's clergy
summary: 'The story of Notre-Dame' (4/5). Partially destroyed by a fire on April 15, 2019, President Emmanuel Macron promised the cathedral would be rebuilt within five years. Due to reopen on December 7, Le Monde looks back on the five years that made this challenge possible.

title: Dogecoin, the crypto joke worth $66 billion
summary: Created in 2013 to parody bitcoin, dogecoin has thrived on Elon Musk's unconditional support. The election of Donald Trump has recently amplified the phenomenon, despite doubts about its economic utility.

title: Pelicot rape trial: Co-defendants plead manipulation and lack of intent
summary: All week, lawyers for the men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot while her husband Dominique drugged her made their closing arguments. Their main defense is that their clients were not aware of committing rape.

title: Trump-Zelensky meeting in Paris 'possible' says Ukraine official
summary: This would be the first meeting between the two since the election of Trump, who has claimed he will secure a ceasefire within 24 hours in the Russia-Ukraine war.

title: Reopening of Notre-Dame: A behind-the-scenes look at the ceremony
summary: 'The story of Notre-Dame' (5/5). Republican, ecclesiastical and televisual − these are the three elements of the ceremonies that will return Paris's cathedral to worship, on December 7 and 8, in the presence of a host of heads of state and prelates.

title: Notre-Dame: How to decipher the cathedral's old and new symbols
summary: An architectural masterpiece with religious, artistic, economic and political significance, the Parisian monument that will soon reopen is, above all, a fascinating repository of symbols, some dating back to the Middle Ages.

title: Notre-Dame reopening to be held indoors due to weather
summary: Saturday's reopening, which comes five years after the fire that devastated the famed Paris landmark, was moved inside after weather service Météo France forecast wind gusts of up to 80 kilometers per hour.

title: 'If the Socialists give the impression of wanting to form an alliance with Macron, it would open up political space for Mélenchon'
summary: It is difficult for the Socialists to compromise with the central bloc, at the risk of being accused of 'betrayal' by the radical left, explains political scientist Rémi Lefebvre.
